instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

Hi,

No water damage on the board.

Value is board connected to power normally.

L3095. 0V
L7520 0V
L7701 0V
L7560 3.34V
L7310 0V
L7320 0V
L7130 7.94

Value while you press the power button

L7520 1.61V
L7310 0.61V
L7320 0.32V

please advise how to proceed.Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
"L7130 7.94"
Is that value on charger only???

Post exact voltage for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 3V42 with only charger connected.
BTW, use original Magsafe 2 charger.

Also need <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
Normal mode:
L7130 7.94 - pin 1
L7130 8.6V - pin 2

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.6V  and 3V42 is present 3.42V.
use original Magsafe 2 charger- yes.
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 3.31V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. - 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.03V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 1.04V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 3.34V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
Stop to check coil voltage on both pins.
You can find the DC voltage on its output pin connected to filter capacitor.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse ( 3-0-3V) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.
If present, then check if all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at the same moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  drop pulse 0.4-3.39V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  drop pulse 0.4-3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> on smc trigger getting different V pulse between 0.4-1.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> on smc trigger getting different V pulse between 0.2-0.8V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on smc trigger getting different V pulse between 0.4-1.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> on smc trigger getting different V pulse between 0.4-1.4V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
In this case you should have pulse at all big coils; check that.
Also check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Inspect <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
yes we have pulse on all big coils
also pulse on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> area looks good. 
Any more ideas? Or we hit a deadend?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no booting - no water damage - no image - no fanspin - light on magsafe
threads.message:
Check all power rails from pages 55/56.

Also check voltage on all L/C blocks near CPU, close to edge board; both sides of each coil.
